title: Offline-ready static website bundle (standalone index.html with local CSS/JS/assets)

requirements.summary: Create a complete standalone offline static site bundle (index.html + local CSS/JS/assets) that runs by double-clicking index.html with no server and no network.
acceptanceCriteria:
A new folder exists that contains a complete offline site with this structure:
/project-root
  index.html
  /css
  /js
  /assets
  /images
  /fonts
Opening the offline bundleâ€™s index.html via double-click works in a modern browser (Chrome/Edge/Firefox) with no network access required
No external (CDN) dependencies are used; all libraries, icons, and fonts referenced by the offline site are present locally and linked via relative paths
No absolute paths (e.g., /css/app.css) or localhost/server URLs are used in HTML/CSS/JS; only relative paths work from the offline bundle root
The offline site loads without console errors on first load

file_operations.description: Create the offline bundle entrypoint HTML with semantic structure (header/nav/main/footer), and link local stylesheet and scripts via relative paths (e.g., ./css/styles.css and ./js/app.js) so it works by double-clicking without any server.
Create a self-contained stylesheet for the offline bundle using only local assets (no @import URLs) and ensuring the layout is readable and responsive without relying on any framework CDN.

Create a self-contained vanilla JS file that initializes after DOM load (or via deferred script) and powers any interactive UI elements (nav toggles, accordion/faq, form validation) with defensive null-checks to avoid runtime errors.
Add a placeholder file to ensure the offline bundle /assets directory exists in version control.
Add a local logo image asset referenced from index.html using a relative path (e.g., ./images/logo.svg), ensuring no external image URLs are required.
Add a local hero/cover image asset referenced from index.html using a relative path, ensuring the offline bundle renders a complete design without network dependencies.
Add a placeholder file to ensure the offline bundle /fonts directory exists even if the bundle uses system fonts initially (and therefore does not reference external font URLs).

requirements.summary: Ensure semantic HTML validity, stable CSS/JS loading order, and eliminate conflicting/duplicate libraries so offline interactions work without errors.
acceptanceCriteria: CSS is loaded before JS in index.html, and JS is loaded in a way that does not require a server (e.g., deferred scripts)
No duplicate library bundles are included in the offline bundle (e.g., multiple copies of the same framework)
HTML validates structurally (no broken/unclosed tags that break layout)
Navigation elements and interactive elements in the offline bundle do not throw runtime exceptions when clicked/used

file_operations.description: Ensure stable loading order (CSS in <head>, JS included with defer), semantic landmarks (<header>, <nav>, <main>, <section>, <footer>), valid markup, and only relative links to local files (no leading slashes, no external URLs, no server-only assumptions).

Harden interactive logic so all click/submit handlers guard against missing elements, prevent default where appropriate, and avoid uncaught exceptions; keep the bundle framework-free (or, if any third-party JS is added later, ensure it is only included once and stored locally).
Review and adjust CSS to avoid reliance on external assets, remove unused selectors, and ensure consistent rendering without requiring additional libraries (no duplicate/conflicting stylesheets).

requirements.summary: Add an English README inside the offline bundle explaining offline usage (double-click index.html) and documenting the folder structure.
acceptanceCriteria: README exists inside the offline bundle folder
README instructions explicitly say that users can double-click index.html to run the site offline
README lists or illustrates the offline bundle folder structure

file_operations.description: Create a short English README describing how to run the site offline by double-clicking index.html, stating that no server/network is required, and documenting the final folder structure (index.html, css/, js/, assets/, images/, fonts/).
